title: Cross-site-Scripting

profile.name: Paragon Initiative Enterprises
profile.about: Cryptography and Application Security Consultants - We Produce Various Open Source Libraries

vulnerability_information:
step:
1: goto https://bridge.cspr.ng/my/account of your account
2. in "Custom Profile field option" check the box and enter xss payload in "display name" field
       payload: "p<script>alert('xss')</script>"
3. update the information 
4. open the account in INTERNET EXPLORER 11 and xss will executed

note: here server is not sanitize the user input properly,
         payload will not work in firefox,chrome browser due to "content-security-policy"
         But internet explorer does not Support "Content-Security-Policy"  so xss will execut

this is stored xss and the display name will visible to everywhere, so its possible to account takeover of ther user

activities.message:
I'm not able to replicate this behavior.

In particular, v1.4.2 (which CSPR.NG currently runs) properly escapes as an HTML attribute. The source code is here: https://github.com/paragonie/airship/blob/32c41962c4229b64483a2a3bcedd17d3ba6df526/src/Cabin/Bridge/Lens/cargo/bridge_home.twig#L8

i just reproduced the issue,
and remember to use INTERNET EXPLORER   11  because it does not support CSP
i will send u also a video

The CSP isn't the issue here. It's not the case that the code is injected and then being blocked by the CSP headers.

Instead, I see it like this:
wait 5 minute, i am going to  make a video
also did you saw the source code,?
Video POC
FINAL VIDEO POC

if u still unable to reproduce use my login id but keep it private
id=pahan12
password=ramkrishna12@
No dice, but I'm thinking about passing the user's display name through HTML Purifier anyway, just in case I'm missing something.

ok... now i got it, where you mistaking 
https://github.com/paragonie/airship/blob/32c41962c4229b64483a2a3bcedd17d3ba6df526/src/Cabin/Bridge/Lens/cargo/header.twig#L12

also you can  goto my account  top right corner you will see "Hello, pahan" -> open it with "inspect element "
and see user input are not sanitize

It's actually happening here: https://github.com/paragonie/airship/blob/32c41962c4229b64483a2a3bcedd17d3ba6df526/src/global_functions.php#L75-L77 What I think *could* be happening, although I still have not been able to reproduce the behavior on my end, is that somehow `
Wait, this doesn't make sense. `__()` is running the input through HTML Purifier anyway.

I found the problem: I'm confusing two different places in the code, based on the original report of going to the home page of Bridge.

This could only be used to XSS oneself, rather than other users, but the avenue for exploitation is nonzero. Get access to their account, if they use a browser that doesn't support CSP, you might be able to exploit the browser.

yes, this is only possible in INTERNET  EXPLORER 11 to exploit because you set CSP in every request. all modern browser  except will block it.
but i really confuse why you are getting  <script> is encoded 
now i am seeing you fixed it and unable reproduce the issue.
now all the user input is sanizited.
and user input if it is <script> then it is render as encoded format, to top right-corner.

> but i really confuse why you are getting <script> is encoded

That too is puzzling me.

> now i am seeing you fixed it and unable reproduce the issue.

Err, yeah. I should probably clarify: cspr.ng is mostly a public testing site for the open source project. I made a change there while testing and forgot to revert it, but it hadn't been committed yet.

If you setup Airship 1.4.2 locally, you'd still be able to reproduce it. I'm going to get a complete patch ready soon and release 1.4.3.

ok.. 
thanks..

hello, few hours ago i checked that bug has been fixed..
but now i checking that it is still reproducable and input is not sanitizing...

In my previous comment, I had said:

>  I made a change there while testing and forgot to revert it, but it hadn't been committed yet.

I reverted the fix on cspr.ng that hadn't yet made it to the codebase after I wrote that comment.

To be clear, the thing in the scope for HackerOne isn't cspr.ng. We don't care if that site gets `rm -rf /`'d six days a week. The thing we do care about is *the code that powers cspr.ng* (and our other open source projects on Github), because it's something that other people might use. This issue isn't resolved if cspr.ng is fixed, because that doesn't help anyone who uses CMS Airship.

ok...then
after  when you release final patch  against this report  you can ping
Fixed in https://github.com/paragonie/airship/releases/tag/v1.4.3, and cspr.ng self-updated.
Fixed, and the fix should be deployed automatically everywhere.
thanks for  bounty.....

hello,  i saw every user input is passed through e('html_attr') function in twig file
so, where i get the code for e('html_attr') ?

https://twig.sensiolabs.org/doc/2.x/filters/escape.html

It's a Twig filter, which escapes data as if it were in an HTML attribute context. It's specifically useful for disallowing HTML.
